Extent of damage: Marooning of Barwer Express
Affecting about one million people and an area of over 5,00,000 hectares including cropped area of 81,000 hectares
Causing floods in West Bengal, Kolkata recieved 18cms of rain on 9th the heaviest fall in July in last 50 years. On the same day Krishnanagar had 26cms. Bagati 24cms and Jamshedpur 18 cms

State: Kerala, Rajasthan, Haryana, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar
Extent of damage: One passenger train was marooned in flood waters near Makrana in Rajasthan.
Completely wiped out
Rail amd road communications with Mumbai were cut off for nearly a month

Pedong recorded 60 cms on 3rd, 70cms in 4th and 76 cms on 5th, Sankos recieved 76cms on 3rd, 64 cms on 4th and 40 cms on 5th. The havoc caused beggars description the area affected presenting a picture of death and devastation all round
Rendered 5 lakhs of people homeless and inundated vast areas of jute and paddy crops

Disrupted telecommunications and road traffic in the Mandi region of Himachal Pradesh and caused floods in the Beas and Ravi inundating vast areas in Hoshiarpur. Kapurthala and Gurdaspur district of Punjab
Affecting vast areas in Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, North Bengal, Assam and Rajasthan. The Jammu flooded many villages near Delhi

Description of Casualties/injured: More than 1,05000 people were reported to be rendered destitude
Extent of damage: Caused extensive damage to agricultural lands and properties, destroying standing crops estimated to be worth Rs. 4 crores

Affected air and train services and throwing the normal life of the city out of gar. Meenambakkam recieved 23 cms of rain on 22nd almost touching the 81 year old record of 23.4 cms on October 31, 1888. Tambaram and Sholavaram, two other suburbs of Madras, recorded 29 cms and 48 cms of rain on that day

Causing Flooded rivers and breached tanks, destroying food crops, rendering thousands of persons homeless and disrupting rail and road traffic in the affected areas. Nearly 40,000 hectares of land with standing rice crop were reported to have benn under water in Thanjavur district the rice bowl of Tamil Nadu
Caused floods in Brahmaputra and its tributaries and inundated vast areas of Jute crops and Paddy fields in the northern districts
Flooding of Alakanda river caused considerable loss of life among pilgrims. A number of bridges, houses and even an entire village in the Joshimath area were washed away

Caused considerable damage to railway track and breaches that disrupted traffic over wide areas. The Narmada and Tapti were in spate resulting in loss of life estimated over a thousand and extensive damage to standing crop and property

Description of Casualties/injured: Flooded vast areas in West Bengal resulting in the death of some 80 persons
